loans.name: Phally

texts.en:
Mrs. Phally S. (in the photo), and her husband, Mr. Sorn Soy, live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh  They married in 1993 and have three sons, all of them in school.

Phally has been selling grocery items for more than 4 years. She buys grocery items from the market for resale at her store in the village. Her husband has been a mason for more than 15 years.

She is requesting a loan of $1,200 to continue expanding her business by purchasing grocery items for resale.

loans.use: To continue expanding her business by purchasing grocery items for resale.

loans.name: Safarali

texts.en:
Safarali has run a livestock business for many years which he has used to support his large family. Since he began his business, he has worked hard to use his earnings to sustain his home and his livestock business which has helped him to achieve his goals. Currently, Safarali needs to purchase more livestock in order to grow his business. Intelligently, he is seeking a loan from IMON International in order to acquire additional animalsfor his farm.  
 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchase cattle in order to expand the business and to improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.name: Rum

texts.en:
Mr. Rum R. (pictured here) is 27 years old and his wife, Mrs. Sophan Phin, is 32 years old. They have been have been married for more than a year and just had a baby boy. They live on an island on the Mekong River about twelve kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Rum’s wife is a tailor. He was a wooden house builder until he transferred the business to his brother. He now wants to start a new business driving a remoque taxi, a motorcycle with a trailer attached to the back. Rum is requesting a loan of 1,000 USD to purchase a motorbike and a trailer to launch his business.

loans.use: To buy a remoque taxi, a motorbike with a trailer

loans.name: Oyundelger

texts.en: Oyundelger G. is 36 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live together in their own ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her daughter attends university while her older son studies at the secondary school and her younger son attends a local kindergarten. Her husband works at Javhlant Bogd Co. Ltd. Oyundelger operates a leather goods manufacturing business. She has been engaged in this business since 1996 and since then, she has managed to expand her business by producing more types of products. Today, she produces a variety of products including leather gloves, key rings and holders, and slippers. She has been successful over the years and has built a stable operation. Oyundelger is hopeful for the future and is looking to expand the business. She is a responsible and hardworking person. She is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase leather materials and sewing machines for her business.

loans.use: To purchase leather materials and sewing machines

loans.name: Sam-Oeun

texts.en:
Mr. Sam-oeun P., is 26 years old and his wife, Mrs. Mom Phorn (pictured together in their wooden house), is also 26 years old. They have been married since 2005 and have three sons, all of whom are still young. Besides his children, he also has his parents living with him. The family lives about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

The couple are farmers; they grow rice and vegetables on their farmland in the village where they live. Sam-oeun is asking for his first loan of 1,200 USD to buy fabric for his son who is married and a tailor and to purchase weaving materials for his daughter so she can continue her weaving business.

loans.use: To buy fabric for his son, a tailor, and weaving materials for his daughter

loans.name: Bùi Thị Thường's Group

texts.en:
Bùi Thị T. is a 40-year-old married woman who has two school-aged children. She lives in the town of huyện Yên Phong - tỉnh B. Ninh. Bùi is the group leader of a four-member group loan offered by SEDA. The official name of this borrowing group is Cụm Nguyệt Cầu 1 - nhóm 03 (Nhóm 03). While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Bùi raises cattle to sell. She has been in business for over nine years and earns approximately 2,800,000 VND a month.

In 2008 Bùi joined SEDA to gain access to its financial services. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,152,000 VND from SEDA that was used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. She is now requesting a new loan, her third from SEDA, of 7,392,000 VND that will be used to invest in expanding the business. Bùi plans to use the additional revenue generated to further expand her business.

About the other borrowers in the group:

1. Kiều Thị Huề is a 64-year-old woman who is requesting a 7,392,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock. 2. Nguyễn Thị L. is a 53-year-old woman who is requesting a 7,392,000 VND loan to support her specialized retail store. 3. Lê Thị B. is a 57-year-old woman who is requesting a 7,392,000 VND loan to support her service-based business.

T. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 9 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, T. kiếm được khoảng 2.800.000 VND. Vào 2008, T. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. T. đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 5.152.000 VND từ SEDA. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua thức ăn gia súc & các loại cung cấp khác. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 7.392.000 VND. Khoản vay sẽ là 3rd khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA. Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm: 1. Kiều Thị Huề (0) là 64 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 7.392.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. 2. Nguyễn Thị L. (0) là 53 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 7.392.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hiệu bán lẻ chuyên dụng. 3. Lê Thị B. (0) là 57 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 7.392.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh trên cơ sở dịch vụ. Về SEDA: Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía B. Việt Nam *Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her cattle business

loans.name: Rentsen

texts.en: Rentsen T. is 32 years old and lives with his wife and two young children in the Hovd province of Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His wife stays home and takes care of their children. Rentsen operates a photo and color printing business in the local community. He has been engaged in his business for three years and has gained much experience and a good reputation among his customers. He is requesting a 600,000 MNT loan in order to purchase a new photo printing machine for his business.

loans.use: To purchase a new photo printing machine

loans.name: Kimsan

texts.en:
Mr. Kimsan O. and his wife, Mrs. Sreyneang Theng, have been married since 2006 and just have a young son. They live a long National Road Number six about 25 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. 

Mr. Kimsan O. is a driver. He drives for a brickkiln in his village. His wife stays at home to take care of their son. Kimsan is applying for loan of $1,000 to build a restroom. He will also use a part of his loan to buy a motorcycle for commuting. 

Mr. Kimsan was not available for the picture, so his wife is pictured.

loans.use: To build a restroom and to buy a motorcycle for commuting

loans.name: Umedjon

texts.en:
Umedjon A. is married with three children. He owns a business selling car parts and accessories. Umedjon is full of ideas. He has rich experience working in this business. Moreover, he is very enthusiastic about his own small enterprise and has a good attitude. Umedjon sets high goals and takes daily action to achieve them. He has been in this business for 12 years. Currently, he has about $3000 in merchandise. Umedjon would like to get a loan of 5000 Somoni to increase his working capital. He believes financial assistance will support him in his endeavors. He is determined to work on his entrepreneurial dreams to make them a reality, understanding that real success and wealth take time. Umedjon is hoping to generate more profit and provide for his children, who are now in school.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes having been a key post along the Silk Road and having witnessed the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to epic mountain passes, a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC, and communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language. Today it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to provide poor and low-income clients with a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing an expanded range of car parts

loans.name: Sopheap

texts.en:
Mrs. Sopheap C. (in the photo) and her husband, Mr. Sopheap Pen, live in a small village along National Road Number Five about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They have been married since 1998 and have three children: two sons and one daughter. Two of them attend school and another one is still young. 

The main source of income comes from her husband, who has full-time employment in Phnom Penh. Sopheap stays at home to take care of her children. Sopheap has requested a Kiva loan in the past. Now she is applying for her second loan of $1,000 to repair the house where she lives.

loans.use: To repair her house

loans.name: Nasridin

texts.en:
Nasridin is a dedicated entrepreneur who is sometimes accused of being a workaholic. Five years ago he started a small business selling groceries. He picked a good location for his business, one that was convenient and filled a market niche, and he has poured his energy into making it successful. Nasridin, a kind, attentive man who tries to take care of his customers, has requested a loan to help open a new selling location and purchase more grocery items to sell. He’d like to continue expanding his business so that he can increase his income. Nasridin’s goal is to earn enough income to purchase a self-contained heating unit for his home. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes its role as a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs for store

loans.name: Azam

texts.en:
M. Azam is 49 years old and lives with his wife and their five children. He is a man who from an early age was characterized as a hard-worker and very dedicated to his cattle-raising business. Azam saw this as an activity that would enable him to earn additional income due to the high demand for these animals in the markets. His challenge now is to improve the breed, but in order to do so he will have to feed them properly.

Azam wants the best for his children, a desire that gives him the motivation to continue improving as both a father and farmer. This farmer yearns to expand his business in order to improve his family living. To do so, Azam is requesting a loan to buy animals of a better breed in order to improve their quality.

loans.use: To purchase cattle in order to expand the business

loans.name: Tserendolgor

texts.en:
Tserendolgor L., age 60, lives with her family in a traditional housing tent called a ger in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Both of her sons operate their own private businesses, while her husband is retired. Since 2005, she has been operating a felt-manufacturing business, producing a variety of felt slippers in her home. Her business is sustainable now as she produces each pair of slippers at a cost of 1500MNT and sells her products at a price of 3500 and 4000 MNT through her son's stall. Her production capacity is 40-60 pair of slippers per week.

Tserendolgor has received two loans thus far and has proven herself as a trustworthy customer. Very honest and well-organized, she says, " Now, I am planning to open my own workshop and to hire two more workers." She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase two sewing machines for her felt production.

loans.use: To purchase two sewing machines

loans.name: San

texts.en:
Mr. San S. (pictured here) and his wife, Mrs. Sinoun Phal, live in a suburb of Phnom Penh City. They have been married for more than five years and have two daughters.

The couple has been operating a business raising pigs and chickens for more than three years. They have received two Kiva loans in the past. In order to continue expanding their business and improving their standard of living, San is asking for another loan of $1,000. He will use the money to purchase additional piglets and to buy food for the pigs.

loans.use: To purchase additional piglets and to buy food for pigs

loans.name: Hoeun

texts.en:
Hoeun L., 31, lives with her husband, Sok-eng Rin, 34, in a small village along the Mekong River, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They were married in 2002 and have two young children: a son and a daughter. Hoeun and her husband are in the photo above.  

Hoeun has been working as a cleaner for a year now. In the past, she used to be a silk weaver. Her husband is an auto repairman. Hoeun is applying for a loan of $1,000 to purchase a new motorbike for commuting. Her motorbike broke down often, was costly to repair, and consumed more gasoline than newer motorbikes. Hence Hoeun has decided to sell it and wants to purchase a new motorbike.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorcycle for commuting

loans.name: Tserenmyadag

texts.en:
Tserenmyadag S. is 45 year old and lives with her one daughter and husband in a Mongolian nomadic dwelling called a ger in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her adult-aged daughter currently attends university, and her husband works as an electrician in the local kindergarten.

Tserenmyadag has been operating her grocery store in a rented space since 2009 and has found success with it. She hopes to expand her business, and her dream is to open her own big grocery store. Tserenmyadag is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more products in order to increase her working capital.

loans.use: To purchase more products

loans.name: Nurullo

texts.en:
Nurullo is married with three children. He owns a small store that sells car parts. His business is located close to a car maintenance shop. This gives him an opportunity to have many repeat clients and a stable business. Nurullo has been in this business for 12 years. During this time, he has developed a good business network that supplies him with the parts his clients order. Nurullo would like to borrow 7500 Somoni to purchase spare parts in bulk. He has gained a reputation for responsibility with his financial obligations and for keeping his word. We are happy to have another opportunity to assist him with the operation of his business.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase a broader range of car parts

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Sok P., 49, and her husband, Ret Kim, 50, live in a small village on National Road Number 2, about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They were married in 1979 and have two sons and three daughters, all of whom are married. While one lives in the family home, the other four live outside.

Sok is a farmer; she grows rice and vegetables on her farmland in the village where she lives. Her husband is employed full-time in a company delivering pure drinking water. Sok is asking her first loan of $500 to purchase a trailer to carry vegetables to sell.

loans.use: To purchase a trailer to carry vegetable to sell.

loans.name: Tuya

texts.en: Tuya D. is 30 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Uvs province, Mongolia. She lives with her family in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent home. Both her daughters attend a local elementary school while her son has not yet reached school age. Tuya manages a raw materials trading business in their town with the help of her husband. They have been engaged in this business for seven years and have built a stable and successful operation. Over the years of business, they have managed to greatly improve their family's quality of life. Their earnings have enabled them to have their own assets such as fenced land, livestock, and a car and garage. Today, their working capital exceeds 2,000,000 MNT, including their livestock. Tuya is a very modest and communicative person and says, "We will try to sell our livestock at high price and improve our car." She is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase 100 pieces of livestock.

loans.use: To purchase 100 pieces of livestock

loans.name: Sharofat

texts.en:
Sharofat is a hard-working business owner from Dushanbe, Tajikistan. Her business is selling the fabrics used for sewing the national dresses. Sharofat has been running her business for 12 years and has gained much experience. She is divorced from her husband and has two children. Sharofat’s business has become the main source of income for her family. Her son also is engaged in her business. Sharofat has requested a loan of 5000 Somoni to add to her working capital. Her business is growing. Financial assistance will help her to continue operating successfully and supporting her family.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase fabrics

loans.name: Soy

texts.en:
Mr. Soy S., and his wife, Mrs. Sreyvet Dam, live in a small village off of National Road Number 2, about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been married since 1995 and have two daughters; both of whom are in school.

Soy has been driving a motor taxi for more than five years, while his wife is a garment factory worker for more than six years. This is the second loan taken out by Soy. He is asking a loan of $300 to concrete his house foundation.

loans.use: To concrete his house foundation.

loans.name: Mehridin

texts.en:
Mehridin N. is 50 years old. He is married and has 4 children. Mehridin is hard-working and has fought to provide for his family and educate his children. He has great cattle breeding experience because he has observed it since he was a boy. Over time he has increased his sales and now he needs assistance investing in his business. The business has been going well and he would like it to continue to grow. Mehridin has applied for a loan of 4000 Somoni to buy young cattle. He and his family thank you very much for the support that you offer them in continuing this business and helping them give their children a better quality of life.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase young cattle to expand his business.

loans.name: Kealy

texts.en:
Kealy P., 50, and her husband, Chamroeun Khen, 55, live in a suburb of Phnom Penh, about 15 kilometers from the city. They have been married since 1977 and have eight children: five sons and three daughters. Five of her children are married and live separately, and the other three live in the family house. 

Kealy is a rice farmer, while her husband has been a primary school teacher for 35 years. She is asking for her first loan of $300 to purchase a sewing machine and fabrics to support her daughter's tailoring business.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine and fabrics for her daughter’s tailoring business

loans.name: Sotha

texts.en:
Mrs. Sotha V., 38, and her husband, Mr. Sophaneth Mao, 43, live in a suburb of Phnom Penh, about 25 kilometers from the city. They have been married for 15 years and have six children: five sons and one daughter. Four of them attend school and the other two are still young.  

Sotha has been working for a non-profit for seven years, while her husband has been a driver for 10 years. She is asking for her first loan of $1,200 to purchase a motorcycle to get to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for commuting to work

loans.name: Lhagvasuren

texts.en:
Lhagvasuren D. is 51 years old and lives with his wife and two adult daughters in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He and his family live in their own 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent and fence; they purchased it with a previous loan. His two daughters are students and his wife works as a private businesswoman. 

Lhagvasuren operates a watch repair center in a small stall next to Mongolian Educational University, Ulaanbaatar. He also sells a variety of small souvenir products through his current repair center. He has been operating his watch repair center since 1995, after graduating from vocational training as a watchmaker. Over the many years of business, he has gained much experience as a clockmaker as well as having built up a successful and stable operation. He hopes to expand his business. 

Lhagvasuren is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to buy watch repair tools in order to increase his working capital.

loans.use: To buy watch repair tools

loans.name: Manibadraa

texts.en:
Manibadraa N. is 43 years old, a single man who lives with his mother, brother and nephew in Chingeltey district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His mother is retired while his brother works as a loader in the Bayangol Hotel. 

Manibadraa worked as a servant in the housing committee between 1985 and 1987, and in 1987-1988 he was employed as an assistant worker in Temuulen-Minj Co., Ltd. In 1988, he had an accident and became disabled. He started to operate a wireless phone service at the Huchit Shonhor, one of the main market in Ulaanbaatar in 2000 and since then has built up a stable operation. 

His earnings have enabled him to put up a building that will be used as a grocery shop from 2010. He says, " Nowadays, my old business is not operating very successfully because everyone has a cellphone today." Manibadraa is requesting an 800,000 MNT loan in order to purchase more inventory to open his grocery shop, located in his own yard.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Than Thi Le's Group

texts.en:
Than T. L., the group loan's head, is 50 years old with three children, two of whom are attending a vocational school. She is a farmer who grows rice, part of which she uses for her family and part to sell. She also raises 400 chickens for eggs. She used a loan from SEDA’s credit program in 2004 very effectively. Currently, Than is requesting a loan of 7,194,000 VND to buy feed for her chickens.

Other members of the group:

Tiep T. N. is 59 years old with three children. She is a farmer who is raising 200 chickens. She would like a loan of 5,014,000 VND to buy feed for them.

N. T. N. is 33 years old with two children who are in secondary school. She is raising 400 chickens for their eggs. She needs a loan of 7,194,000 VND to improve her chicken house.

Mai T. L. is 34 years old with two children who are attending secondary school. She runs a small grocery shop. She would like a loan of 6,322,000 VND to buy more kinds of products to meet customer demand.

Trinh T. N. is 40 years old with two children. Being a farmer, she grows rice and raises pigs for their meat. She is requesting a loan of 5,014,000 VND to buy pig feed.

loans.use: To buy feed  for chickens

loans.name: Natsagmaa

texts.en:
Natsagmaa H. is 32 years old and lives with her father, husband, and two daughters in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live in their own apartment. Her father is retired and stays at home while her two daughters both attend local secondary school. 

Natsagmaa currently operates a small bakery in her local area. She started her own business in 2006 by importing cars from Japan to sell for a profit after working as a manager in the Best Land C., Ltd between 2003 and 2005. She operated a children's clothes trading business in the Narlag trade center in 2008 and has been managing a bakery business since 2009, making a variety of breads and baked pastries. She runs her bakery production in a rented space and produces eight types of bread and pastry to supply  to up to eight different places/organizations. She pays rental fees of 300,000 MNT per month. 

Over the short period of operation, she has managed to increase her working capital and has built up a stable and successful business. Also, she was able to hire two more workers. She pays a monthly salary of 500,000 MNT each to her employees. Her monthly average net profit is between 500,000 and 600,000 MNT. 

She is a very active, diligent and hardworking businesswoman and says, “ I am saving money for my children's future education." Natsagmaa is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT  loan. She will use this loan to purchase cake boxes at 700,000 MNT and with other monies left over from the loan plus her own cash, she is planning to buy a new micro bus for her bakery business.

loans.use: To buy a new micro bus for her bakery products

loans.name: Otgonbayar

texts.en:
Otgonbayar L. is 40 years old and lives with his wife and four children in Hovd province, western Mongolia. He and his family live together in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. The elder three children, ages 15, 12, and 10, all attend local secondary school while his youngest son, age 6, attends a local kindergarten.

Otgonbayar  operates a meat retail business in his town’s local market with help of his wife. He started his first grocery trading business in 1997 and has been operating his meat trading business at the local market since 2008. Over the many years of business, he has built up a stable and successful operation as well as gaining much experience as a businessman. He purchases a variety of meats from the countryside and sells it at the market for a profit. Otgonbayar is requesting a 1,800,000 MNT loan to purchase livestock at wholesale prices.

loans.use: To purchase livestock at wholesale prices to retail as meat at the market

loans.name: Lusine

texts.en:
Lusine G. is married with three children. She has been trading in women’s and men’s clothing and shoes since 1996. Lusine rents a trading booth at one of the city markets. While her husband helps her run the family business, she travels to the neighboring countryside to purchase stock.

This business is the only source of income for Lusine’s family. The couple has been investing in their children’s education to insure their future prosperity.

loans.use: To purchase new inventory

loans.name: Dong Thi Nguyen's Group

texts.en:
Dong T. N. is 36 years old and has three children who are attending high school. She is a hardworking farmer. Every day she goes to the field to cultivate rice and corn in paddies of 4,500 square meters. She also raises chickens for eggs to increase her daily income. Dong joined our credit program in 2006 and is a good group leader. Currently, she needs a loan of 6,322,000 VND to buy fertilizer and chicken feed.

Luyen T. N. is 44 years old and is raising 200 chickens for eggs and ten pigs. She is in need of a loan of 6,322,000 VND to buy feed for them.

Tinh T. D. is 49 years old. She is a farmer who grows rice and corn in paddies of 5,000 square meters. She would like a loan to buy fertilizer.

Thuy T. L. is 39 years old with three children who are in high school and secondary school. She makes rice cakes to sell at wholesaL.. Now she wants to borrow 7,194,000 VND to buy rice to make her cakes.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and chicken feed

loans.name: Suhbold

texts.en:
Suhbold E. is 25 years old and a married man. He lives with his wife in Hentiy province, Mongolia. He and his wife live in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent in their sibling's yard. His wife operates a vegetable trading business while he drives a taxi within his town. 

Suhbold has been operating his taxi service since 2008 and has built up a successful and stable business operation. His daily business revenue is between 18,000 and 35,000 MNT and his daily operating cost such as fuel for his car is 8,000 MNT. His wife sells a variety of vegetables that she grows in their own field, at an outdoor stall at the local market during the harvest season. Her daily sales revenue is between 15,000 and 30,000 MNT. This year, they harvested 600kg of potatoes, 500kg cabbages, 300kg of carrots and 50kg of beets. The continued growth of both businesses, transportation and vegetable trading, enabled them to decorate their house and helped them to improve their quality of life. 

Suhbold works hard and is a modest and open-minded person. He says, "I hope to operate the business well so that it is stable. My dream is to purchase a new car for myself, therefore from now on, I am starting to save money in order to achieve my dream." He is requesting an 800,000 MNT loan to purchase engine, tires, and shock absorbers for his car.

loans.use: To purchase engine, tires, and shock absorbers

loans.name: El

texts.en:
Mrs. El A. has established a small home in which she lives with other family members in the best territory located in Battambang Province. She is married, but doesn’t have a child yet.

El owns a piece of farmland that she and her husband inherited many years ago from their grandparents, growing rice and vegetable crops for the purpose of eating and selling. El A. now needs to borrow a loan to buy fertilizer to fatten her crops that are not growing well.

Mrs. El A.’s husband is pictured.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer for her crops

loans.name: Phuong

texts.en:
Phuong T. N. is 39 years old and has two children who are in high school. She is an experienced farmer in growing sticky rice, which has best wholesale price. Besides that, she also raises 10 pigs for meat. Every three months, she gets 3,000,000 Vietnamese Dong (VND) in profit from raising the pigs. 

She has used loans, which she has been getting since 2006, to invest effectively in her business. Currently, she wants to have a loan of 8,502,000 VND to buy food and fertilizer.

loans.use: To buy food, fertilizer

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine M. is happy-looking because she feels so excited about the support that she got from Kiva lenders for her fishing business in her previous loan. Josephine prays they may all be blessed. She has a sound team relationship with Kiva as well as her ASHI partnership. Now she is requesting another Kiva loan to continue growing her fishing business. She has been able to improve her business due to her access to credit with a bigger loan from Kiva Lenders. 

In addition, Josephine revealed the huge impact the loan has had in her family, as she was able to afford to buy desired food items for the family to eat and still ensure prompt weekly payment of her obligation to ASHI and cover other needs. She is also happy because she is able to feed her husband well and still cover the needs of the family. 

What Josephine hopes right now is that their business will continue to be successful, because this has been their life, providing for their family. They love what they do in creating business achievements.

Josephine's fishing business has been very helpful in achieving her children's dreams. For her it is a pleasure to see the accomplishments in her business and family. With her children growing, she wants to see them have the best in life. Above everything else, Josephine’s happiness and contentment in life, being a mother and a wife, depends on the success of her business.

loans.use: To continue supporting her fishing business

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita V. is from the village of Brgy. Salamague, Lamut, Ifugao. She is 55 years old. Teresita is married and has eight school-aged children. To make a living, Teresita owns & operates a business raising pigs for breeding. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Teresita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase feed & other supplies. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Teresita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase feed & other supplies

loans.name: Nelly

texts.en:
Nelly Y. is from the village of Brgy. Sta.Cruz, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 45 years old. Nelly is married and has 4 children. To make a living, Nelly owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for breeding. Nelly has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Nelly joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nelly has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock. Nelly is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Nelly from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 42-year-old married man and the father of 2 school-aged children. He has owned a citrus fruit business for the past 10 years. He cultivates only citrus products on his land. He is the main income provider for his family. He uses plastic tents to grow his produce. These tents allow him to better monitor product quality as well as growing his produce for more months during the year. He works independently in his business. 

Today, he is requesting a loan of US$ 1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l.  to purchase needed supplies for his agriculturA. work.  In the future, he is planning to grow his business and cultivate other agriculture produce but he hasn't yet decided which type of crops.

loans.use: to purchase needed supplies for his agricultural work

loans.name: Kasenyi Community Progressive Group, Mubende

texts.en:
They say that hard work pays and a very hard working and friendly M. Dorothy has gained from the fruits of hard work. She started her restaurant enterprise over 30 years ago, offering catering services in the Trading centre in Mubende. Here she prepares breakfast meals, local dishes for lunch and supper for the customers.

 Due to good management and esteemed customer care, the business has maintained customers for a long time. She created a good market by maintaining high levels of hygiene. Most of her customers are town dwellers. With this loan, Dorothy wants to put in place good furniture and buy foodstuffs and drinks as she looks at improving the quality of services offered. This will enable her to get more customers, earn more profit and be able to cater to her family's needs like education. She is very optimistic about achieving a self-sustaining life with more income coming her way.

loans.use: To restock the restaurant with more food and furniture

loans.name: Soam

texts.en: Mrs. Soam T., age 56, lives in Kompong Chhnang province. She has been spending most of her life farming rice crops. Soam T. learned this specific skill from her grandparent when she was young. She is married, but her husband died of senility years ago. She currently resides with three children. One of her children has a suitable job and the other two are single. Soam T. is taking out her loan to buy a secondhand motor for her employed children to drive to work. Any remaining cash from the loan she will use towards sustaining her crops.

loans.use: To buy a secondhand motor.

loans.name: Akuha Nomuha Group, Ibanda

texts.en:
N. Madina of Akuha Nomuha group in Ibanda, age 29, is a single mother of one child. She has been operating a spare parts store for bicycles and motorcycles for a period of over 12 years in Bufunda, Ibanda. 

Through doing this with determination and hard work, she has been able to make 300,000 Ugandan shillings on a weekly basis.  She uses this money to meet her family's daily requirements including buying food and paying tuition fees. For a long time, her motive has always been setting up a bigger spare parts shop, as there is a ready market available. This would enable her to get more income to educate her child. Madina was introduced to this business by her uncle who was doing the same business. Through establishing good relations and saving more money, she was on track to open up her own store. Therefore, with this loan, Madina will restock her business and be able to earn more sales revenue.

loans.use: To restock her store

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 42-year-old married man and the father of four children of whom two are still attending school. He makes his living as an experienced taxi driver. He has been involved in this business for the past 15 years. His main service route is between his town and the surrounding areas. And he also offers private transportation services. 

Today, he is requesting to borrow US$ 1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to perform maintenance work on his taxi including changing the tires and repairing the engine.

loans.use: to perform maintenance work on his taxi

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John N. is a sole proprietor  businessman who operates  a butchery in an urban setting near a school. His customers are mainly students. He has been in this business for  four years and earns an  income of Kshs.9,000 per month.

John is married to Margaret Wambui and together they are blessed with four children; three of the children are secondary school students and the last born is in primary school. His wife does farming and this adds to the family income. John was introduced to KADET LTD by an existing client of   KADET; he has no history with any other MFI. He  is applying  for his first loan of Kshs.20,000 from  KADET, with which he  intends to buy more goats to have more meat to sell in his butchery.

His major aim is to firmly establish his business and see his children get a better education in future. He is 43 years old and  very hardworking.

loans.use: To buy more goats to have more meat to sell

loans.name: Fena Fena Tukore Group, Mubende

texts.en:
K. Frank of Fena Fena Tukore Group is a hard working and ever-optimistic 33-year-old married father of one child. He operates a growing agro produce business in Kanseera Trading Centre, Mubende. He buys and sells cereals like maize, beans, millet and more. 

With a business longevity span of three years, Frank has managed to significantly sustain and improve his family’s welfare by paying his bills and general family welfare. To all appearances, his future business prospects look promising with 600,000 Ugandan shillings coming in monthly out of his business. He envisions an even greater profit margin as he gets this loan, anticipating being in position to buy more stock for the business. This will enable him to expand business by opening more stores, earning more revenue and living a self-sustaining life.

loans.use: To purchase more stock

loans.name: Janice

texts.en:
Janice B. runs a "sari-sari" (general) store. Sari-sari stores basically sell small quantities of various foodstuffs, grocery items and beverages. “Sari” is a native Filipino word for variety. This is a small store that is either attached to the owner’s house or in a small native cottage, not far away from the owner’s house. Such stores are convenient for people in the village who lives far from the marketplace. 

Janice started her variety store through her initiative in dealing with customers. She wants to continue her business; it gives them good proceeds to support the education of her three children. She is requesting a loan of PHP18,000 so that she can have the funds needed to buy more food products and basic household necessities. This will allow her to attract more customers and increase her sales. With profit from her business, she wants to buy a hog for fattening for supplementary income. After four months of raising or fattening, pigs will be sold either alive or slaughtered for meat to be sold per kilo. Her long-term goal is to have her own restaurant someday, so that Janice will give the opportunity of employment to others. 
  
Janice dreams of growing her variety store into a mini-grocery store and expanding it to another village, so as to send her three children all the way through college, and to have their own beautiful house and lot for comfortable living. Her three children are her inspiration to pursue her variety store. She now feels very happy about the service of ASHI and its KIVA partnership. It gives them a great possibility to pursue their family dreams. She hopes that they continue the service for a long time and help many families who want to get ahead.

She has shown herself to be hard-working to make her dreams come true and hopes that her business will continue to be more productive and improve the overall living conditions of her entire family.

loans.use: will buy more food products and basic household necessities

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 36-year-old married man and the father of three school-aged children. He is an experienced construction worker. He is especially talented at completing woodwork and gypsum board projects. He has been working from the past 15 years in this occupation. And he started working independently in his business back in 2000. He works hard to satisfy all alone the demands of his family. 

Today, he is requesting to borrow US$ 1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l.  to purchase more wood for his work on his newest project. In the future, he is planning to expand his business by opening a construction office and working with some construction entrepreneurs.

loans.use: to purchase more wood

loans.name: Youssouf

texts.fr:
Monsieur Youssouf S. est homme marié de 26 ans et père d’un enfant qui vit avec sa femme et son enfant dans le quartier Massablacoura de la ville de Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur Youssouf S. a fréquenté l’école coranique pendant des années. Après ces études coraniques, il décida de mener des activités génératrices de revenus. Il a tenté pendant des années, différentes activités, mais sans succès.
Il finit par  apprendre auprès de son cousin, l’achat vente   des articles divers d’une boutique. Avec une expérience de 6 ans, il maîtrise son activité et est très sollicité. 
Afin de renforcer son activité, il décide d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso pour acheter une quantité importante d’articles divers pour sa boutique. 
Il est à son troisième prêt avec Soro Yiriwaso et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés
Il s’approvisionne à Bougouni et à Bamako auprès des grossistes.  Sa clientèle est composée de la population locale.
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 75.000FCFA qui sera essentiellement utilisé pour agrandir sa boutique.
texts.en:
Mr. Youssouf S. is a married man who is 26 years old and father to one child; he lives with his wife and child in the Massablacoura neighborhood of the town of Bougouni (the Republic of Mali's third administrative region). Mr. S. went to a coranic school for a number of years. After finishing his coranic studies, he decided to turn his hand to activities which would generate some income. For years he tried out different activities but without any success. He ended up learning from his cousin how to buy and sell a variety of products in a shop. With six years experience he now masters his activity and is in great demand. 

In order to strengthen his business, he decided to join Soro Yiriwaso's loan program so that he could buy a significant quantity of items for his shop. He is on his third loan from Soro Yiriwaso and all the previous loans have been repaid in full. 

He gets his supplies from wholesalers in Bougouni and Bamako. His customer base is made up of local people. 

He is expecting to make a monthly profit of 75,000FCFA which will be used mainly to expand his shop.

loans.use: Purchase of goods for his shop

loans.name: Anhbayar

texts.en:
Anhbayar E. is 33 years old and lives with his wife and two sons in their own apartment in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His oldest son, 3, attends a local kindergarten while his infant son stays at home. His wife works as an accountant for a local company.

 Anhbayar sells medicines that are used for all kinds of kidney diseases such as kidney failure, nephritis etc, through his mother's grocery shop. He started his business in 2009 by selling medicines which are imported from France. 

Anhbayar is a very peaceful and gentle man. He says, "My dream is to open my own pharmacy." He is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to use for product advertisement costs in order to increase his sales and attract more customers.

loans.use: To use for product advertisement

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 51-year-old married woman and the mother of three children. After the death of her husband, she decided to take on the operation of his land by herself and continue her husband’s agriculturA. business. She used to help him, and that’s why she had the experience to do it. Two of her children help her with the family expenses and she has one child who is still attending school. 

Today, she is requesting to borrow US$ 1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l.  to purchase agriculture supplies such as fertilizer and seeds for the coming harvest. In the future, she hopes to continue her business properly and continue earning a good income for her family.

loans.use: to purchase agriculture supplies such as fertilizer and seeds for the coming harvest

loans.name: Rollos

texts.en:
Rollos R. is from the town of Trinidad. He is 32 years old. Rollos is married and has three children. His children are aged 6, 3, and 4 months. Rollos has a sari-sari (variety) store and he grows pigs, too. He sells fruit, charcoal and other products. He grows pigs for fattening and sale. Rollos wants to acquire additional merchandise to sell at his store. 

Rollos joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rollos is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional merchandise and pig feed. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support his family.

loans.use: additional merchandise and pig feed

loans.name: Cirila

texts.en:
Cirila C. is from the town of Trinidad. She is 55 years old. Cirila is married and has six children. Her eldest child is 35 years old and the youngest is 18. To make a living, Cirila owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting & harvesting  a variety of vegetables for sale. 

Cirila joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cirila has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Cirila is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizer and other farm inputs. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizer, and other farm inputs

loans.name: Chagnaadorj

texts.en:
Chagnaadorj J. is 43 years old and lives with his wife and four children in  Mongolia's capital city, Ulaanbaatar. He and his family live together in a traditional Mongolian tent home called a 'ger'. His oldest daughter is a student and the other three children all attend local middle school. 

Chagnaadorj produces wooden saddles and his wife sells those items in a stall at Narantuul, the largest and main market of Ulaanbaatar. He has been operating a wooden saddle making business since 2006 and has built up a stable and successful operation. In addition, he operates a taxi service using his own car to supplement his earnings. He says, “I want to expand my businesses and provide a good education for my children." He is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more wood materials for his saddle-making business.

loans.use: To purchase more wooden materials

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David M. is a gentleman who is 31 years old and married to a lady named Gladys Mwithanga. He is a hawker for clothes within the busy Dandora estate in Nairobi. He is able to make a profit of about Kshs 15,000 every month from his hawking business which is just enough to cater for the needs of his family.

David joined KADET after his friend introduced him. He had no previous knowledge of how microfinance organizations work. He is now accessing his first loan which he will use to buy more clothing stock for his business. 

His future plan is to own many boutiques in other places.

loans.use: Adding more clothes stock for his hawking business

loans.name: Jargalsaihan

texts.en:
Jargalsaihan L. is 37 years old and lives with his wife and two daughters in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He and his family live together in their own 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Jargalsaihan's two daughters attend a local high school. His wife works as a maid in the school. 

Jargalsaihan operates a successful transportation service using his truck. He has been engaged this business since 2009, transporting loads to destinations between Bars and Narantuul. Both are very popular and large markets in Ulaanbaatar. His monthly average income is 780,000 MNT. For the future, he wishes to provide higher education for his daughters. 

Jargalsaihan is a very hardworking man and is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan both to purchase spare parts for his van and do some construction on his home.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for the van he uses to provide service

loans.name: Munguntsetseg

texts.en:
Munguntsetseg D. is 49 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Hentiy province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a 'ger', a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her oldest son lives and works in the Czech Republic while her middle daughter works as a doctor in a hospital. Her younger son attends university and her husband is currently unemployed. 

Munguntsetseg operates a construction supplies business in a rented space at the local market. She has been engaged this business for past 10 years. Since then, not only has she built up a stable and successful operation but she has also gained a wide customer base as well as much experience over the years. Her daily average income is between 50,000 and 60,000 MNT and it reaches up to 100,000-120,000 MNT during peak season.

 In addition, she is beginning to operate a grocery store in a rented space in the 'ger' district and earns a daily average income of 150,000-200,000 MNT to supplement her income. She is planning to expand her grocery  business and build a sustainable operation. She is a very honest and hardworking person and says "I have been working all my life. Time can not wait for us therefore I must to work hard all the time. My dream is to have my own grocery shop in the future. " She is requesting a 2,900,000 MNT loan to purchase more inventory for her grocery shop.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Remembering the experiences during her youth, Gina T., now 32 years old, has regrets. She got married at the very early age of 16 and never finished high school. Now she has seven children to take care of. She has promised herself that she would work hard and teach good values to her children so that they will not suffer the same fate as she. 

Gina is a very dynamic mother who has always dreamed of a bright future for her children. She joined Ahon sa Hirap, Inc., a partner MFI of KIVA in the Philippines, in 2006. She started selling fish in their community but now after several years her business has improved. She is applying for a loan of Php 20,000 to finance her now enlarged fish trading business. She will buy more fish and supply directly to fish vendors in the market. 

She has already identified buyers and she is planning to market her fish in other towns and provinces. She is hoping that KIVA lenders will support her business plans so that she can generate more profit and be able to pay for her children’s schooling. Her ultimate dream is to send her children up through college and see them earn a degree. 

Note: Please ignore the date on the picture; the setting on the camera is not properly adjusted. That's why the date is still 2007.

loans.use: to buy assorted fish in greater volume to wholesale

loans.name: Yay

texts.en: Mrs. Yay K. is a modest person living in Kampong Chhnang, where she has been earning a living as a farmer, raising a few chickens and crops. She is married with four school-aged kids. She has a life partner in her husband who works as a community medical doctor in the hospital. Yay K. says that she has always hired a farmer’s cow to help plow her farmland where she uses to grow crops every year. She hopes to reduce the hiring fees by requesting a loan to buy a pair of cows which she can use to plow her farmland and to raise for offspring as well.

loans.use: To buy a pair of cows

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Purchase tools and equipment

loans.name: George  Kamau

texts.en:
George Kamau  M.   is 43 years old, married to Leah Wakarima who is a business lady, and they have two children aged 12 and seven years. George operates a little retail shop in South Kariobangi, an urban setting where most of his customers are low-income earners and few middle-income earners. He has been in this business for about seven years, with a monthly income of Kshs.25,000.

He has never borrowed from any other MFI and was introduced to KADET by a friend. George is applying for second loan of Kshs. 50,000 with which he intends to add more stock worth Kshs.15,000, and open another shop that will cost him Kshs.35,000. In that way he can be in a position to serve his customers effectively.

He hopes to save the anticipated profit and later venture into spare parts sales and see his children get a better education and improve the family living standard.

loans.use: to add Kshs.15,000 worth of stock and open another shop for Kshs.35,000

loans.name: Daisy

texts.en:
For four years, Daisy has already been a member of Ahon sa HIrap, Inc. (ASHI) – a partner MFI of KIVA in the Philippines. She is 42 years old, married with two children. Managing a variety store is the primary source of their income. Her husband is involved in fishing and has put up a fishpond. Again she is applying for a loan of Php 20,000. Half of the loan will be used to finance their fishpond and half to buy additional grocery products for her variety store. 

Daisy is proud that she is now financially independent and helps her husband in providing for their basic needs. Both their children are in college that is why the couple works hard to pay school fees and allowances for their children. Daisy also plans to improve both businesses to have stable income and gradually accomplish their dreams in life. The couple hopes and pray that ASHI and KIVA will always be there to support all their goals in business and for their family.

loans.use: To finance their fishpond and buy additional grocery items for her store

loans.name: Jeanne

texts.en: Jeanne is married. She is 40 years old, with four children whose ages range between 20 and 11 years old. Her husband is a driver. She sells cattle which is used for slaughtering and it's now two years since she started her business. With this loan she will buy more cattle and with the profits she will pay her children school fees. In the future, she wants to buy a vehicle for transporting cattle.

loans.use: To buy cattle for slaughtering

loans.name: Dramane

texts.fr:
Monsieur Dramane G. est homme marié de 31 ans et père de 3 enfants. Il vit avec sa femme et son enfant dans le quartier Massablacoura de Bougouni (Région de Sikasso)
Monsieur Dramane G. a abandonné l’école dès son âge pour se consacrer aux activités génératrices de revenus. Après  des années activités  tous azimuts  sans succès, il finit par opter pour l’achat vente d’articles divers de boutique. Avec une expérience de plus de 2 ans, il maîtrise son activité.
Pour obtenir un fonds de roulement conséquent, il décide d’adhérer au programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son premier prêt.
Il compte acheter avec son prêt divers articles pour la boutique. Il s’approvisionne à Bougouni et effectue sa vente dans sa boutique à une clientèle diverse et variée.
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 50 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour subvenir aux dépenses de la famille et réinvestir dans les activités.
texts.en: Mr. Dramane G. is married and the father of three children.  He lives with his wife and children in the Massablacoura neighborhood in Bougouni (in the Sikasso region).  Mr. Dramane G. left school early in order to devote himself to revenue-generating activities.  After years of business attempts realized without success, he finally opted to buy and sell various items in a small shop.  With more than two years of experience, he has mastered his business.  In order to obtain a consistent working capital, he has decided to join Soro Yiriwaso's loan program, with whom this will be his first loan.  He intends to use his loan to buy various articles for his small shop.  He buys his stock in Bougouni and conducts his sales in his shop to a diverse clientele. He intends to earn a monthly profit of 50,000 FCFA which will be used to support his household expenses and to reinvest in his business.

loans.use: Buying various items for his shop

loans.name: Githinji

texts.en:
Githinji  K.,  41 years old, is married to  Ruth Mukonyo. They  live in Dandora, just few kilometers from Nairobi City, where most of his customers are low- and middle-income earners. He operates a barber shop and this he has been doing for 17 years with a profit of Kshs 15,000. He also offers a Bible binding service which is an additional source of income.

He has borrowed from other MFI and was introduced to KADET LTD by a friend. Now he is applying for his second loan of Kshs. 40,000 to expand his services by opening another barber shop in a different place. He desires to grow his business and hopes to install a kerosene pump in the near future.

loans.use: to expand his services by opening another  barber shop

loans.name: Marie Claire

texts.en: Marie Claire, a hardworking 45-year-old mother, has seven children between the ages of 3 and 26, one of whom is married, while the rest are in school.  Marie Claire's husband is a plumber and he works hand in hand with her to raise their children.  Marie Claire sells meat, and with this loan she will buy more meat to sell, intending to expand her business to make more profits.  Her dream is to support her children up to university level.

loans.use: To buy more meat to sell

loans.name: Myagmardolgor

texts.en:
Myagmardolgor T. is 50 years old and lives with her husband and two daughters in an apartment in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. Her two daughters both attend a local middle school. Her husband works as the head of a department in the Bureau of Standards.

Myagmardolgor operates a training center for traditional bootmaking in the local community. She teaches how to make Mongolian traditional boots and felt products to her customers. She also produces a variety of traditional boots and felt products herself to sell for profit. She has been engaged in this training service since 1995 and has gained significant experience with her sustainable business.

Myagmardolgor is a very polite and gentle woman. She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase a sewing machine and materials for her bootmaking training center. She hopes to continue expanding her business and establish her own big training center.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine and materials

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
A hardworking entrepreneur, Elsa J. has raised and sold hogs for years from Sibalom in the province of Antique, earning her sound weekly profits. Her hogs are sold either alive or slaughtered for their meat to be sold per kilo. Elsa’s main challenge has been her small amount of working capital that thus limits the number of pigs she can raise at a time.

in 2009, Elsa joined ASHI, one of Kiva’s first partners in the Philippines. She is very grateful for its secured access to capital and other services such as savings and insurance. This loan of 18,000 PHP is to help Elsa buy more hogs so as to satisfy her local customers’ demands. She thinks that commercializing and expanding her business will enable her to earn more money which she would use to pay for tuition for her two children who are in college and to take care of other family needs.

With access to additional working capital from Kiva supporters, Elsa is hopeful her dream of her children attaining college degrees will be achieved. Elsa’s wish to give her children a brighter future is what motivates her day.

loans.use: To buy more hogs to raise and sell

loans.name: Temps De La Grace Plus Group

texts.en:
Gyka K. is 68 years old and a father of six children. He is the leader of the Community Bank group named “Temps de la Grace Plus,” which means “grace period” in English. It is composed of fifteen members united in solidarity through receiving loans from Hope, a Kiva partner, with the goal of developing their businesses.

Since 2005 Gyka has been in business selling flippers and miscellaneous goods. He joined one of Hope’s groups (part of a DRCongo microfinance program) in 2007 and has received fourteen loans that he repaid properly. Thanks to Hope’s loans, Gyka’s business has prospered and generates a profit of $10 per day.

Gyka intends with his next loan to diversify his business by buying different plastic items to resell at a profit in order to increase his capital. His ambition is to open a plastic goods shop due to high demand in his neighborhood. He has been working hard to achieve his dream.

loans.use: To buy different plastic items to resell

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 20-year-old single man from Lebanon. He lives with his parents and 5 siblings. Seven years ago, he stopped his education and started working in car mechanics. And since 2007, he is a proud new car repair shop owner in his town.  He is thankful for his business income because he is able to help his father in the household. 

 Today, he is asking for a loan of US$ 1500 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase a specialized scanner to examine the cars technologically. He is certain that with the help of the loan, he will be able to purchase the machine and develop his business. In the future, he is planning to purchase more technicA. equipment to expand his business level.

loans.use: to purchase a specialized scanner to examine the cars technologically

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 38-year-old married man and the father of three school-aged children. He has owned a van delivery business for the past 20 years. He works hard to be able to raise his three children and pay for their schooling. He is the main income provider for his family. 

Today, he is requesting to borrow US$ 2000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to perform maintenance for his van including vehicle engine overhaul and body painting. This will be his second loan and he is thankful for the results. He is certain that with the new loan he will be able to perform the needed maintenance and expand his business.

loans.use: perform maintenance for his van

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: The purchase in bulk of foods such as bananas for resale

loans.name: Obéissance Plus Group

texts.en:
Tshibangu is the leader of the Community Bank named “Obéissance Plus” which means “Obedience” in English. It is composed of 15 members united in solidarity for receiving Kiva loans with the goal of developing their businesses.

Tshibangu is 50 years old and a father of ten children. He has been active in his business since 1989. He began his business selling watches. Besides selling watches, he also sells miscellaneous goods. He joined one of Hope’s groups (a DRCongo Microfinance Program) in 2009 and has received six loans. Thanks to Hope’s loans, Tshibangu’s business has prospered and it generates a profit of 20 USD per day.  With the next loan, Tshibangu intends to diversify his business by buying jewelry to resell at a profit in order to increase his capital. 

His ambition is to convert his business into one in the medical field. Due to the high demand for medicine in his surroundings, Tshibangu wants to open a drugstore to meet the people’s need. He is working hard in order to achieve his dream.

loans.use: increasing his stock by buying jewelry and reselling it at a profit

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: The purchase of more stock for resale at his shop

loans.name: Lwamba Development Group-Mityana

texts.en:
Thirty-five-year-old Ben Lwamba K. belongs to the Lwamba Development Group - Mityana. Down the stretch, it is has now been 12 years since he took root in his cash-crop selling business in Lwamba. 

This happy, humorous and sociable father of four has mostly been selling coffee, beans, maize and tea leaves. This is a business he began modestly but at present, it is worthwhile for him in terms of profits. In a month, his profits total up to shillings 400,000. At first he was predominately selling coffee. With this loan, he wants to buy in bulk more crops that he will resell.

loans.use: The purchase of more food crops for resale

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 40-year-old married woman with five children from Lebanon. She is a proud new business owner of a school supplies shop. She also offers gadgets and gift products in her shop. She is asking for a loan of 1000 USD from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to expand her inventory selection before the school season. She has high hopes for the future of her business; she is looking to continue expansion of her business in the coming year. 

Women continue to play an important role in Lebanese society, especially in the development of the family. Women are able to serve as strong role models for their children while also helping to supplement their household incomes.

loans.use: to expand her inventory selection

loans.name: Kanyegaramire Tukwatanise, Kihihi Group

texts.en:
Sam N. of Kanyegaramire Tukwatanise, Kihihi, is a hardworking and ever-optimistic 29-year-old married father of one child. He operates a business growing and selling agricultural products, especially rice, in Kanyegaramire, Kihihi.
 
With a business longevity span of four years, Sam has managed to significantly sustain and improve on his family’s welfare. To all appearances, his future business prospects are promising, with 300,000 Ugandan shillings coming in monthly out of his business. He envisions an even greater profit margin as he gets this loan, anticipating being in a position to buy more rice for the business. This will enable him to expand the business by opening up more stores and also being able to earn more revenue and live a self-sustaining life.

loans.use: Stock of rice for resale

loans.name: Akutwala Ekiro Development Group-Mityana

texts.en:
Peragia K. rises as early as the larks. With the kind of business she undertakes -- food sales --  this is extremely invaluable, as clients normally prefer to purchase foods at the crack of dawn. Welcome to the world of this 45-year-old, where it is survival of the fittest in a cutthroat business and the ones with better wits can gain an advantage over those who are not in touch with the reality of this kind of business. 

Subsistence farming was her first major preoccupation. Though she still holds it in high value, she says selling the crops that she harvests is a better and worthwhile business proposition. Her business accrues 45,000 shillings weekly. With this loan, she wants to buy in bulk more cash crops for resale. She belongs to the Akutwala Ekiro Group-Mityana.

loans.use: The purchase of foods in bulk

loans.name: Tongolo Development Group - Lugazi

texts.en: Selling fish is a lucrative business that has transformed the livelihoods of many Ugandans, especially those who live around areas where the River Nile flows. One of those areas is Lugazi. H. Hussein, age 38, has been one of the benefactors of this trade in his area. He has been plying this trade for the last 10 years. It is a business he began with encouragement from a close friend. He says he used the savings from his farming business to jump start this business. His determination, perseverance and diligence have been paying off, as exhibited by the 200,000 shillings he makes in a month. Hussein also ekes out a living with a commercial motorcycle business. Hussein is married with six kids and belongs to Tongolo Development Group - Lugazi. With this loan, he wants to buy new fishing nets for his business.

loans.use: To purchase new fishing nets

loans.name: Zibula Atudde Women's Group - Mityana

texts.en: N. Yudaaya, age 24, says she dropped out of school to embark on an agro produce sales business. She is quick to point out that it was not deliberate, but she just became a victim of circumstances. It was a decision that had to be backed up with determination, poise, courage and belief. Prior to that, she was more inclined to sell clothes. She still sells clothes, albeit on a smaller scale. She makes 700,000 shillings monthly. N. has a common cause with the borrowing group called Zibula Atudde in Mityana. With this loan, she wants to buy more cash crops like bananas and Irish potatoes for resale.

loans.use: To purchase more cash crops such as bananas and potatoes

loans.name: Bulamu Development Group - Mityana

texts.en: K. Mary of Bulamu Development Group - Mityana is a 33-year-old mother of four. She has spent 15 years in her medical clinic business in Bulera - Mityana. It is a business she began soon after dropping out of school. With 200,000 shillings as weekly profit, her business can stand in no better stead. She also makes do with profits from a poultry farm. With this loan she wants to purchase more drugs for her clinic.

loans.use: To purchase more drugs for her clinic

loans.name: Namulesa Twekembe-Lugazi Group

texts.en: Tailoring is a business preoccupation 32-year-old N. Diana has been inclined to for the last 14 years in Nangunga-Lugazi. It is a business that has been putting food on her family’s table all this while and she has no regrets as to why she began it. Of paramount importance have been the skills she got at the tailoring schools she attended. What has also come in as a winning attribute is her hard work attitude. Diana, who is a jolly mother of four, says she also operates a pay phone business and sells bananas. In a month, her profits equal 140,000 shillings and with this loan, Diana who belongs to Namulesa Twekembe Group-Lugazi, says she is going to give her business a new lease springboard. In essence, she says she is going to buy more cloth-making textile material and also improve her other businesses.

loans.use: To purchase more cloth-making material

loans.name: Nakaseeta Savings And Credit Group-Mityana

texts.en: N. Edinus of Nakaseeta Savings and Credit group is a 36-year-old married mother of four. She has been at the decision making hierarchy of her relatively modest hotel business in Mityana Town for three years. She was previously an agriculturist. The thought of making money out of operating a hotel with crops from her gardens crossed her mind later on. Edinus describes herself as sociable and easy going. 40,000 shillings is what she makes in a week. She belongs to Nakaseeta Savings and Credit Group in Mityana and with this loan she wants to revamp her hotel with better furniture and better foods.

loans.use: To revamp her hotel business with better furniture and better food

loans.name: Yairo

texts.en: R. Yairo has subsisted on a produce sales business for more than 4 years. He is a fledgling agro-sales business trend setter whose example is bound to stand out as a benchmark for other people in his home area of Nyaruharo, Rukungiri. Many in his area preoccupy themselves with self-destructive activities instead of working hard and taking on their family responsibilities. With his hard work ethic, R. Yairo has managed to take firm root, earning 250,000 UGX monthly. With his savings, he has managed to diversify his small business, selling coffee, beans, bananas and milk. This has not been easy, however, as he has had to grapple with many adversities such as the unpredictable weather patterns resulting in fewer farm suppliers. He is looking forward to upgrading his banana plantation with this loan. He hopes to be in a position to provide for his children’s education costs as he looks forward to improving the household income.

loans.use: buying supplies such as manure

loans.name: Kyandago Development A, Kihihi Group

texts.en: It is now 11 years since B. Jeninah started up her farming projects and specialized in selling bananas in Kihihi, western Uganda.
